reviewerDisplayName: The Mother Fucking Major F R E T
reviewText:
FEAR 2 is the sequel to FEAR (obviously). You play as a Delta Force soldier named Michael Beckett who is sent to capture Armacham (the bad guys from 1) president.

There are some dramatic gameplay changes from the 1st game, and they are all absolutely terrible. No more awesome gunfights with smart AI. Now you just fight waves of dumb enemies. AI is really inconsistent. They go from not even noticing you after you've shot two of their team mates in the same room and circling around a grenade you've just thrown to having the reactions of someone who just snorted crack and with aimbotting accuracy. I will also note they have serious trouble throwing grenades.

Another change was the removal of peak buttons. This wouldn't ♥♥♥♥ me off so much if this game actually gave you a reasonable amount of health but instead you are forced to hide by corners and pick enemies off. No more running into rooms with slow-motion on. Try that and you better hope you kill all enemies before slow mo runs out. If I really need to manipulate cover, I need more than a press E to flip over a ♥♥♥♥ing table here.

To begin with the guns all feel incredibly useless. The SMG sounds okay at best, and the pistol sounds like it's less useful than harsh language. The combat shotgun's sound is laughable and pathetic. Even some of the better weapons like the assault rifle, (semi) automatic shotgun and sniper rifle don't feel extremely powerful. There aren't many new weapons. Most of them are re-skins. Only new are the automatic shotgun, sniper rifle and laser gun which are somewhat welcome additions.

The one thing I thought could save the game was the sections where you get to pilot a mech, but some idiot decided that there should be some grainly filter over the screen that gets even worse as you take damage. It absolutely looked horrible and I found it incredible distracting.

About the only thing improved from the original game is the fact that there are more varied environments for levels, but that's nothing if I'm not enjoying the time spent in said environments.

All in all the gameplay felt like a cookie cutter shooter which needed to give the player one or two more health packs and armour pickups (at least on hard).

Story wise this game is kinda like the first. It gets very predictable, especially if you've played the first game. The scares are the same, although I did feel this game was a little more scary than the first, it still failed to terrify me. Most of the jumpscares were fairly predictable, and there was only so many times that seeing Alma and bloody rooms could be even somewhat unsettling.

All in all, I'd advise you play the first FEAR game. It runs rings around this game. If you need something else to hit that slow-motion Hollywood badass fix go check out the Max Payne series. The only reason I could possibly recommend this game is if you've played the first FEAR and wish to see how the story plays out.

4/10

reviewText:
I wanted to like F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin.  I really did.  As a fan of the original game, I was equal parts relieved and excited at the news of Monolith’s re-acquisition of the F.E.A.R. license.  The masters had recovered their legacy, and I couldn’t wait to welcome Alma back into my nightmares again.

Unfortunately, after finishing F.E.A.R. 2, it became disappointingly apparent to me that in the time between Monolith’s loss and recovery of the F.E.A.R. IP, they forgot what made the original game a genre-defining game, as they have led its sequel into potential-dashing mediocrity.

Immediately, players are introduced to the new player character, Michael Beckett (A.K.A. “Bucket.”  Seriously.), whom we quickly discover that Alma kind of has a thing for…apparently.

But more on that later.  The mainstay of F.E.A.R. 2’s gameplay is the series’ standout action elements, returning in all their bloody, hyper-reflexive glory.  Sporting smooth, polished gunplay and the return of F.E.A.R.’s standout enemy A.I., F.E.A.R. 2’s gunfights will rarely leave players wanting.  The welcome addition of several new enemy types, new combat mechanics, and the inclusion of a few mech-combat sequences help to keep combat fresh, but have a tendency to completely distract players from any semblance of horror for fairly lengthy intervals.

Complementing these features are modernized visuals and several welcome deviations from the series’ previously monotonous environments. Certain set-pieces, especially the series’ hallmark hallucinations, are surprisingly well-composed, lending F.E.A.R. 2’s presentation a certain degree of artistry.  These features notwithstanding, it should be noted however, that while F.E.A.R. 2’s graphics and level design far surpass those of its predecessor, they only just meet the par of its contemporaries, and the same can be said for the game’s decidedly sub-par multiplayer.

Having established those things, I feel like I’ve written the rest of this review before.  Namely, Monolith has made a lot of the same mistakes with F.E.A.R. 2 that Timgate Studios made with the Perseus Mandate expansion pack before it.  From the odd choice of departing from the original game’s art style to F.E.A.R. 2’s nonsensical story, the game just doesn’t really feel like a F.E.A.R. sequel, in appearance or spirit.

Relying more upon jump-scares than psychological dread, F.E.A.R. 2’s horror segments are more nerve-wracking than they are unsettling, and this trend infects the story as a whole.  Its departure from Point Man aside, the game doesn’t even seem to remember its own timeline throughout its disjointedly illogical narrative, and many of Alma’s actions throughout the game just come off as arbitrarily forced.   She has no reason, especially early on, to take notice of Beckett, and yet she harries, attacks, and molests him like something out of Navi’s darkest nightmares, keeping many of the game’s would-be horror sequences from feeling more than marginally threatening, and instead lending them an unwelcome atmosphere of uncomfortability.  Seriously, there are segments of this game that are just plain unpleasant to sit through, especially its “twist” ending, which really robs players of any sense of climactic achievement.

As an FPS, F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a bloody good time, but as a horror game, much less a proper F.E.A.R. sequel, it falls disappointingly short.  Despite its solid action, its neutered horror and vague, paranormally hormonal storyline bar it from living up to its legacy, and its replay value is middling at best after single-player’s completion.  I can’t say that recommendations come easily for it, especially for fans of F.E.A.R., but FPS junkies like myself may enjoy this momentarily dark departure from the usual fare of run n’ gun action.

Rating: 5.8

Visuals: 6
Audio: 5
Controls & Mechanics: 7
Atmosphere & Experience: 6
Entertainment Value: 5

reviewText:
A shooter that simply ticks all generic shooter boxes.  Dimly lit corridors? check.  Warehouse/crates? check.  BOO! check,  bullet-time? check, Explodey tanks lying around waiting for you to make them go boom, crawlspaces? check! and let's not forget the bit where you're on a train and baddies keep coming at you from another track... etc

Environments: Corridors, do you like dimly lit corridors?  I hope you do.  You might be lucky and get some warehouse/crate action!!!  You get released from the tiny outdoor areas a few, all to brief times, then it's back to corridors and subway tunnels (yes, we're back to subway tunnels etc).  There are some better zones later on, big factory settings that at least have some sense of scale, but you wait a long time for them.

Shooty Bang Bang: The guns work, not much interest, the assault rifle is pretty much the entire game.  The hammerhead is nice, but no other weapon than assault rifle is necessary for 99% of the game.  Shotguns are cool for the things that charge you like abominations and assassins, but assault rifle is fine for them too.  Weapons that might provide some variety are castrated by lack of ammo.

Tank bits are fun, of course, tank bits are always fun.

The Story: Spooky bits are pretty much eye candy, there's no serious effect on the game, it's a straightforward shooty game with gratuituous spooky effects seemingly tagged on at the last minute to remind you that this is a FEAR game. Yes it does make you jump from time to time, effective in the same way as a screamer video on YouTube.   The levels are strewed with pointless info drops, saves having to script an interesting game I guess, having your plot all scrawled down on little data pads.  Ignore them.

Enemy AI: basic stuff.   You walk along, the game will auto-save to let you know there's a firefight coming, creep, crouch, bullet-time headshot them till they're all dead. rinse-repeat... in corridors.

The Ending:  Was that an ending? Ummm. ok...  I guess this was an Episode of something...

Overall: Meh, dull, unimaginative, fails to make any use of the IP.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin quite simply isn't a F.E.A.R. game. It's Call of Duty with its only tie to the first game being the little telepathic supernatural undead psycho chick Alma.

All the highpoints of the first game, the atmosphere, the alternation between fast unforgiving gunplay and atmospheric level progression are not present in this sequel. The first game's expansion packs of Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate were weaker than the original game but far stronger in design + story than this. The Mech suits are interesting but the rest of the game is unoriginal as dirt.

Furthermore, F.E.A.R. core gameplay involves the Replica soldiers, supernatural monsters, and the U.S. Army unit of First Encounter Assault Recon. This game starts you out with a lengthy section of fighting Armachan soldiers murdering Armachan employees. You're not fighting as the F.E.A.R. Point Man or operative (as in Perseus Mandate) but a Delta force squad practically taken from COD: Modern Warfare.

In conclusion, I would only recommend this game if you're a COD addict and need another cheap fix. The original F.E.A.R. with its expansion packs and F.3.A.R. are better than this. At least in F.3.A.R. you get some interesting gameplay  as Paxton Fettel, the undead brother from hell.

reviewText:
Many claim that this game shouldn't bear the name of FEAR, but no, since the two games are quite similar.

There are enemies that come from very limited entrances, and you just slow down the time to shoot their heads until they become ragdolls every time... nothing has changed. Also, the unnecessary amount of variations for grenades and very poorly written story (or, lack thereof) is in this game, too.

That aforementioned many also say that this game lacks the fear factor that the first game has. It is an undeniable truth that this is not a good horror game, but the first game isn't, too. Voice of the many bashes this game for only having jump scares, but the first one does, too.

Vox populi is also that this game should be cleansed with the righteous fire of PC gamers because this game doesn't have the ability to lean, which the first one has. While it is obvious that the feature is removed for the sake of making the game for consoles along with PC, that feature is completely irrelevant to the first game, to begin with. There is simply no need for leaning, and it isn't even realistic, as nobody trained properly would peek-and-shoot from covers while making entries in as close quarter engagements as the two games depict. There are very few areas that call for leaning in both games, but they are too rare to warrant implementing it.

This is FEAR 2, a sequel to that mindless shooter. It's good for what it is.

reviewText: The original FEAR is unquestionably a very bizarre game.  It was an action FPS that focused on brutal over-the-top slow motion.  And it was also a horror game.  A Japanese-style ghostly little girl creepy atmosphere horror game.  You know... the kind of thing that's diametrically opposed to over-the-top slow motion action.  Also, it was about psychically-controlled clone soldiers under the command of a rogue cannibal who was in turn being controlled by his mother's vengeful ghost.  And it was 100% serious about all this.\n\nRead more[videogamepotpourri.blogspot.com]

reviewText:
Yes, I guess this game was a step down compared to the original F.E.A.R., but it's still a great game with a solid campaign and decent multiplayer (while it lasted). It still felt like a F.E.A.R. game (unlike the abomination of the third one) with an interesting story (that unfortunately falls apart a little in the second half, and relies a lot on codex entries) great gunplay and A.I., some fantastic locations, great graphics, good atmosphere and scares. The multiplayer itself was actually also pretty decent, with some absolutely amazing maps, free DLC, simplicity, and a fun as ♥♥♥♥ mode called Armored Front (essentially a symmetrical Capture Point style game where each team unlocks a giant mech). Unfortunately, there were no true dedicated servers, an overpowered ASP rifle, and a ranked system that never worked.

Overall, I'd give this game a 8.0/10. It's still a great game that holds up well both on it's own, and with the F.E.A.R. name. Honestly, the worst thing about it is that it just wasn't as good as the original, which is a perfect 10/10 in my book.

I'd give the Reborn DLC a 4.0/10. It's mildly decent, but I'd get it only on a sale. The premise is cool, but it doesn't really go anywhere, so the story is really lacking, and there's like zero scares. Some of the best firefights and environments out of the whole game though.

reviewText: In FEAR 2 you play as Sgt. Becket, a Delta force operative. The game starts a few minutes before the ending of FEAR 1. FEAR 2 is a lot more polished than the first game, with improved graphics, and interface. The sound effects are great especially with surround sound. The story doesn't really have much to it. It basically consists of you getting from Point A to Point B, while you meet a few characters along the way and pick up intel documents. The first game had a sense of mystery behind Alma in a way that you did not really know what kind of situation you had gotten yourself into. The gameplay in FEAR 2 is still great, with different weapons and grenade types, and AI that still has traits from FEAR 1 such as squeezing the trigger as they die causing their guns to fire off round until the clip empties, or jumping into the nearest body of water when they are on fire.\n\nBottom Line: If you liked FEAR 1 you should definitely get FEAR 2, but don't expect a great storyline.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 2 is a really well put-together story-driven shooter. I feel like it expanded nicely on all the main mechanics of F.E.A.R. Plays like a hollywood action-thriller with, of course, the trademark horror twist.

The scares are played up a lot at the beginning, but by the finale all the Alma stuff just got weird. The horror element takes a backseat to fast-paced gunfights with the Replicas throughout the middle. However, the game still does well at giving the player plenty of suspense, as some areas (like the school) have excellent story pacing. You never know whether to expect a lot of action or another scare.

The game was much too short, and the ending was anti-climatic. It didn't feel like a challenge at all. I still recommend it however, especially if you're interested in the canonized continuity of F.E.A.R.

reviewText:
In a quantum leap of effort over F.E.A.R., the producers of F.E.A.R. 2 have decided to eschew the generic character naming convention of the first game, and give the protagonist of F.E.A.R. 2 a proper name. In the first game, the lead character was imaginatively named Point Man after Gun Man was rejected as being too specific since he can do Matrix style slow-mo kung-fu and kill without guns. Violent Guy was also considered but rejected as being too generic. Neo was already taken. This time you play a special-ops soldier named Michael Becket.

Continuing the story from the first game, the incredibly powerful ghost Alma has just been released from containment. Alma had previous been locked up in a science lab for over 20 years. Naturally being surrounded by nerdy science types for over 20 years and having to endure their annoying and incessant chatter on Hadron-colliders, Star Trek and whether Anakin really had a father or not, has driven Alma completely insane. Her top priorities are understandably to kill everyone (especially nerds) and getting a (non-nerd) boyfriend. Being a violent and vengeful ghost she sees a kindred spirit in trained-killer Becket and falls madly in love with him. Not only is Becket a hunky special-ops type that's good with guns, he's also handy about the house and not a bad cook. Unfortunately Alma being out of the dating scene for over 20 years does not know that the rules of dating have changed significantly since her time. Instead of the more sensible dinner and movie, Alma proceeds to woo Michael by killing all his friends and scaring the bejesus out of him. Tragically this doesn't work out too well.

For those familiar with the first game, the narrative style is identical and predictable, vacillating between fast-paced action set pieces and slow-burn psychological horror. Slow-mo is back but Mechs are a new addition. F.E.A.R. 2 is a worthy addition to the franchise and fans of the first game will probably enjoy this one. Best played at night and in the dark - just watch out for the Puppetmaster.

reviewText: Pur perdendo in parte il gusto horror del primo capitolo resta FEAR fino in fondo, con un'azione ancora più frenetica e sanguinolenta. Il sangue esplode dappertutto e ogni tre secondi Alma cercherà di spappolarci il cervello.\nUna tempesta di violenza in prima persona, armi che rispondono alla perfezione, e un livello di difficoltà decisamente soddisfacente se giocato in Difficile.\nCome al solito c'è chi vi dirà che il primo capitolo di FEAR è migliore, tuttavia resto convinto che siano ugualmente lodevoli entrambi in modi diversi, poiché il primo introduce le vicende e il mondo di gioco, mentre questo seguito (per certi versi quasi uno spin-off più che un seguito) porta la combo horror-violenza assurda-azione frenetica-slow motion all'ennesima potenza. Che dire, consigliato a tutti, soprattutto agli amanti dello splattern.

reviewText: I could only stomach 30 minutes of this game but it seems to be a console-centric, UI blinking mess. Perhaps there's a decent game buried underneath the Fisher Price press this" "do that" "look here" interface but these overt distractions detract crucially from the subtle macabre experience I expect from FEAR. The essence of horror gaming is to make the protagonist feel disempowered
date: and this is impossible when the HUD always tells you exactly what to do next.\n\nA grave disappointment of a long-awaited sequel and not worth your time or money if you expect a game resembling the original."

reviewText: A pretty fun shooter.\nIs is very similar to the first FEAR game - a tactical shooter with over-the-top action. However, it isn't scary at all. What it has are awesome graphics and design that really hooked me, great voice-acting and stunning visual effects. The ghosts and phantoms are particulary pretty. My main complaint is lack of enjoyable multiplayer and WAY too much Bullettime in singleplayers. You can use it all the time. The game's battles really shine in normal speed, but this is missed due to playing the whole game in SlowMo, becuase you can and have no reason not too.\nTry the demo first. If that's your style then buy.

reviewText:
I've just finished F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin.

Postivite:
+Graphics are so much better! Actually game looks a lot like Call of duty serries.
+A lot of attention to detail. I can't imagine how much time developers spend just crafting scenes with mutulated enemy corpses. Stop sometimes and admire the details.
+You will be able to take a ride in Titalfall like robot suit (Thermovision included).
+You now can carry 4 guns instead of 3.
+The difficulty is about right this time. 1st F.E.A.R was too easy.
+Game is much more epic.

Negative:
-Atmosphere is not that great as in first F.E.A.R
-Ability to lean over the corner removed.
-Game is less scary. Basically it's call of duty with some scares.
-Story is still not very involving.
-Suprisingly AI is dumbed down in comparisson with 1st F.E.A.R
-Explosions and slowmo somehow less satisfuying this time. Granates look weak.
-They got rid of ability so save game whenever you want. That's kind of shame. Not because
it's harder to play this way but because when getting new gun I like to fool around and when reaload game and play it seriously :))
-A bit dissapointing ending.

Don't get fooled by all the negative things. It's still really good FPS game and I don't regret investing my time in it.
But if you are looking for great survival horror look elsewhere.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: F.E.A.R. 2 is an okay console port, but lacks in many features that were present with the last installment such as: Leaning, quick-saving, usage of extra mouse buttons, and a higher difficulty. The only one of these that really changes the game into a 'rush in the room with slo-mo' is a lack of lean. The first game you have to lean to live, if you don't then you die. although this could be exclusively applicable to the higher difficulties. You could get through the first game just using slo-mo but where is the challenge in that. It's not entertaining to be forced with this sloppy console port. Graphically it's great, gameplay is what really lacks and the first game is the only one I can truely recommend.

reviewText:
Ah... F.E.A.R. 2. Great expectations and some slight disappointments. But the Pro's outweigh the cons this time. The game ignores the expansions (Extraction Point & Perseus Mandate) and begins approximately an hour before the climatic end of F.E.A.R. Now... go play F.E.A.R. if you want to know the details of the story. The gameplay is solid and the mix of slo-mo powers along with high levels of combat and gunfights are kept in F.E.A.R. 2 and the paranormal elements are still there, if not as frequent as in F.E.A.R. The story, music, gameplay is amazing, however the MP is lacking the funfactor that was present in F.E.A.R.

But aside from that, if you want a game with over the top, giant robot mech shooting, crazy slomo explosions and movie moment gunfights along with a sheer brilliant and well blended scare factor (Alma is really freaky) then go ahead and get this game!

Also! Buy the DLC! It's great and also sets up the return of an evil character in F.E.A.R. that is brought back ;)

reviewText: A very underwhelming sequel to the original. Consolized controls (lean is gone, you can't holster your weapons anymore, hitmarkers when shooting enemies), less fancy effects during gunfights (bullet decals are generic tiny holes now and there's less particle effects in general), smaller environments and a pretty bland storyline that mostly consists of fetch quests in your way to reach a particular location. The shooting is still fun and the environments are more varied compared to the first game even if they're still nothing special outside the school level, but it's a significantly more generic experience than its predecessor. Also, don't bother with the DLC until it drops to u$5 or less, it's been over four years and they're still asking u$10 for a new 40 minute campaign.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 2 takes place around the same time as F.E.A.R. but played by another protagonist named Beckett. The game no longer allows you to save whenever you want, it uses checkpoints but it makes these at frequent spots so it doesn't get frustrating at all. It introduces great new weapons and at some points you will even pilot a mech.
The storyflow, plot development and character interaction is also well done. It makes you feel you're in a real world where you will care what happens to all the NPC you interact with.


FEAR 2 - Reborn.
In this short add-on you play as a replica clone soldier named Foxtrot 813 who for a mysterious reason is drawn by the ghost of Fettel from the first F.E.A.R. game. The story won't make much sense until the very end. But after playing F.E.A.R. 3, this I have doubts if this story is canon at all. It doesn't fit with F.E.A.R. 3 at all and I blame that game's very poor story for it (read my review there).
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Good action game.  There are a few instances where you just may get the CRAP scared out of you during gameplay.  It's a very unique blend of feeling fearful, being alone in the dark (lighting is pretty awesome in the game), and being surrounded by very intelligent 'replica' enemies and mutated psycho beings that are all out to get you.  Some really freaky cutscene AND action segments that are bizarre and eerie involving Alma, the weird little girl, so all in all the game is quite fun, can scare you good, and has great action.  Play this game on highest settings and highest difficulty and you will be challenged!\n\nI've always liked the FEAR series so perhaps my review is a little biased but I loved it, it is a great game, and that's that.   In my opinion it's 2 thumbs up fun.

reviewText: I played and finished the first F.E.A.R. It was quite eerie and had some great scares. The gameplay was addictive and loads of fun. I then downloaded F.E.A.R 3 and gave it a shot. The gunplay is still amazing as always but many of the horror elements were taken away. It was dissapointing because the game is only 4 hours in length. I finally decided to download F.E.A.R. 2 after a few days. I can tell you one thing, I finished Amnesia twice, played outlast, and many more horror games, but this is scary! In a different way of course. 1.8 hours in and I had chills running down my spine. The zombies are horrifying in this game.

reviewText:
READ THIS BEFORE YOU BUY THE GAME.

I loved F.E.A.R. 1 and the dlcs however F.E.A.R. 2 is just lacking the basic necessities of a fear game. All the good things from fear 1 were scraped and replaced with utter ♥♥♥♥.

In fear 1 you can lean. ( no leaning in fear 2 )

In fear 1 grenades shook the earth and caused mass mayhem as soon as you pulled the pin ( in fear 2 it feels like you're pulling a party popper rather than throwing a powerful grenade)

Fear 1 had an AMAZING hud. Every key was mapped out perfectly and it felt like a simple yet incredible game to play. ( fear 2 is antithetical to this and very dissapointing )

Fear 1 had good game mechanics and the AI were somewhat smarter then the latter game. ( in fear 2 the AI push over plants for cover. For anyone wondering plants do not make good cover. we're talking about little plot plants here )

To sum it all up Fear 2 is still a good game but Fear 1 fans will be dissapointed and ashamed to call this a fear game. Despite being an abomination it is still a fear game through and through and i would reccomend it to anyone looking for a good old game. BEFORE YOU PLAY FEAR 2 PLAY FEAR 1. READ THIS AND TRUST ME YOU WONT REGRET BUYING FEAR 1.

Yours Truly ( insert steam name here)

EDIT: After finishing the game ( i was half way through when i originally posted) i would still reccomend this and even say its a tad better then i thought. Its still an utterly horrible F.E.A.R. game but its an excellent shooter. The weapons are pretty good and the mechsuits are a nice touch. ( they're possibly the one thing that i wish were in the first game) The graphics have been touched up heaps since the first game. Alma even makes reference to this -----------SPOILERS ALERT---------------------- during the school section-----------. This game feels roughly the average length you'd expect a shooter like F.E.A.R. 2 to be but compared F.E.A.R. it's very short. -----------Just a little note. With the original dlc it wasnt made by Monolith so it it isnt considered Cannon. The distrubiting company that distributed the game bought the rights to F.E.A.R. and made 2 dlcs. Which don't really add much but still werent bad. The dlcs are not worth it by the way however if there is a steam sale i would buy it. I got it for 15 Aus Dollars. Know onto the Reborn dlc. The reborn dlc is really short. If you tried you could complete it in an hour to an hour and a half. Seriously the dlc is only like 5 intervals long with no break ups inbetween each interval. I think in all F.E.A.R. games the intervals were a crucial way to make you feel like you've achieved something because basically most of F.E.A.R. 1 is just one big level which i surprisngly liked.

Thanks Again.

It doesn't fit with F.E.A.R. 3 at all and I blame that game's very poor story for it (read my review there).

reviewText: The game falls squarely in the 'alright' category during most of its playtime. There's a decent selection of unique weapons, gunplay and similar mechanics are fine, walking around in mech suits is fun, and the visuals are pretty damn good if you ask me.\nHowever: The things that are supposed to make this game shine, don't quite manage to do so. FEAR 2 is not a scary game by any stretch of the imagination. It pretends to be on the cover, but it's really just an everyday power-fantasy shooter where you mow down waves of enemies. The occasional jumpscare and spooky halucination really aren't enough to make it feel like a true horror game. Aside from that the story is decent, if a bit cliché at times. Unfortunately any impact the story might have had is negated by its absolutely horrendous climax: A cutscene that strips away any input the player might have had and completely fails to resolve the game's main plotline.

reviewText:
I played this at launch and hated it.

I played it in March of 2015 and realized it was a fantastic sequel to a fantastic game.  This game improves on FEAR in almost every conceivable way.  Better gunplay than FEAR, better graphics, better sound and level design.

Where FEAR 2 falls short is in the scare department.  That is to say, it wasn't scary when it came out, and it's not scary now.  FEAR at least nailed the atmosphere and raw tension that came with expecting the next jump.

Shortcomings aside, I consider FEAR 2 to be a close second on my best FEAR game" list; I wish Futhreer was half as good as Project Origin."

reviewText: Fear 2 is the weakest game in the trilogy for me, but even with that in mind it still stands above tons of other shooters in terms of quality and story. It's shorter and more streamlined than Fear 1, and certainly suffers from trying to appeal to a wider crowd difficulty-wise, but at least it doesn't have that weird trying-to-get-with-the-times vibe that Fear 3 had. At the very least, the multiplayer for this is basically Fear 1's, but it actually still works because they didn't use a CD key algorithm that limited them to like 3 million keys.

reviewText:
The refined sequel to what is already a bit of a modern classic, F.E.A.R. F.E.A.R. 2 improves on everything and as a result, plays much more smoothly than its somewhat clunky predecessor.

Graphics are crisp and clear, comparable to Max Payne 2, which means they are still holding up rather well today.

Sound is excellent, much better than the first installment. In particular, the score has seen notable improvement.

Gameplay still rewards a tactical approach to combat, though you no longer depend on your slow-motion ability quite as much as you used to in F.E.A.R. Gunfight are often winnable even without resorting to slow-motion, though using it definitely helps.

F.E.A.R. 2 provides the same type of scares as the first game, so they may sometimes be fairly cheap. Due to the improved visual fidelity, the gore is much more explicite here, however. This game is not for the squeamish.

Any shooter fan should definitely pick this up, even if they didn't like or play the first installment.
